Key Arguments: The bill creates a two-tier system that unfairly privileges politicians, journalists, and educators over ordinary citizens.
Excessive fines and broad application of the code suppress diverse viewpoints and inhibit free speech.
Distinguishing between true and false information is inherently difficult due to evolving knowledge.
The bill could stifle competition and innovation by allowing major industry players to create onerous codes.
The extraterritorial reach of the bill is impractical and unreasonable for foreign digital platforms.
The bill contradicts the principles of the News Media Bargaining Code and restricts access to diverse perspectives.
Notable Quotes: This unjust distinction not only undermines the democratic ideals of our society but also hampers the power of ordinary individuals to voice their opinions.
The task of accurately distinguishing between true and false information is an impossible one, as new discoveries and evolving consensus constantly challenge established facts.
The restriction of diverse viewpoints are alarming and reminiscent of oppressive regimes rather than the democratic society we aim to uphold.
